page.title: 07DOWNE HOUSE
page.content:
DOWNE HOUSE IN DOWNE VILLAGE
Downe House is important to local history because it was the home of Charles Darwin but now it is owned by the Royal College of Surgeons. Darwin lived at Downe House for 40 years until he died in 1882. In this historic house, you can see his study, his microscope and the tools he used . The most valuable exhibit is the original log of the voyage of 'The Beagle'. The oldest object is the fossil jawbone of the Megatherium which Darwin found in Argentina. There is also a Galapagos tortoise which is 100 years old. In the garden there is a mulberry tree which is over 300 years old and the worm stone which was used to find how earth worms move soil. Each year 9 to 10,000 visitors come which is important for tourism.
